body:
Because there are people out there who want to destroy the lives of people with whom they disagree politically. Have you not been paying any attention the last few years? If I am in a guild and mention something about my personal life in a comment and then get into a political argument with some unhinged retard they can just go through my post history to find out what I do for a living, what local guilds I post to and then dox me. I've seen it happen on reddit, twitter and especially facebook. 

I don't understand why anyone would want to be anything other than anonymous on the internet. It's accessible to *anyone* in the world and there are genuine psychopaths out there.

I've seen it happen on reddit, twitter and especially facebook.

I don't understand why anyone would want to be anything other than anonymous on the internet. It's accessible to anyone in the world and there are genuine psychopaths out there.

body:
A friend made a post on Reddit where she linked a source to a volatile localish issue in order for.people to see what really happened. It pissed off the redditors enough (it wasn't even a baiting post, just trying to calm the waters), that they went through her history to pull any detail (including location and travel subs) until they narrowed down who she was. She then started receiving threatening messages with personal info.  She left reddit over it. Those rabid animals have no limits. 

For me, personally- I figure the only ones who would notice this setting are those trolling through profiles in order to start shit. And, well,, then I guess it speaks for itself. Who has time for that?

body:
I could say any number of things about reddit having a bad culture but really I just like my privacy. I have most, if not all, of my social media accounts set to private when possible. Ruqqus having the feature was a big part of what convinced me to stick around.

I guess in the back of my mind I have niggling fears that somehow I could get doxxed, but I mostly just like to make it a little harder for people to internet stalk me without my knowledge.

body: What do I have to gain by keeping it open? I figure no one needs to see the entire overview of what I said and where I posted it to at the click of a button. What matters is what I'm saying now, not something I've said 5 days/weeks/years ago. Plus it's some nice little protection against mass downvoting or doxxing, even if it doesn't stop anyone from googling my history or whatever if they're really dedicated. Neither has been a problem yet, but better safe than sorry.

body:
>I would also point out the fact that you looking at multiple users profiles trying to view their history, proves that you have been successfully conditioned by that site to engage in that activity.

Not really. I know some users on reddit who say that they look through profiles to find new subreddits. I also sometimes look through profiles to find mod announcements made in the past or to find posts from a series by the same author (like the Ban Wave News here on +WatchRedditDie, except I can't do that because the author's profile is private). It's not always about "constructing ad hominem attacks".

![](https://i.ibb.co/MR5FfzB/sfrohne.png)

body:
On Reddit there were subs that had a list of "blacklisted subs"  these subs would ban anyone who ever took part in a "blacklisted sub".

I also came across multiple times where people on Reddit shat on me for something I had said in the past which was completely irrelevant to the argument.

plus if I remember correctly Ruqqus default is setting profile to private, so why would I go out of my way to change it when there's little to no benefit to setting it to public, but a decent amount of benefits for keeping it private?

body: I want to be as close to ghost as possible. I can find info on a lot of people I know with a simple Google search. I can't find anything on me and I'd like to keep it that way. I try to be hard to peg so if we ever go full USSR, the KGB/DHS/NSA/whatever our nutty friends in Washington come up with will have a hard time with me.
